summary: Embryonal carcinoma is a relatively uncommon type of nonseminomatous germ cell tumour that occurs in the ovaries and testes. It can present as a palpable mass or widespread metastases, and can be pure or a component of mixed germ cell tumors.
diagnosis: Gross examination showing pale grey, poorly defined tumour with haemorrhage and necrosis
Microscopic features including indistinct cell borders, mitoses, variable architecture (tubulopapillary, glandular, solid, embryoid bodies), nuclear overlap, and necrosis
Identification of blue cells attempting to form primitive tubules (in testicle)
Differential diagnosis from seminoma, teratocarcinoma, yolk sac tumor, and Sertoliâ€“Leydig cell tumor
